HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 4, 1924

A COLLEGE TOWN
Hopkins and Hopkins' activities have more friends now than ever
before. The Maryland football game, notable track successes and
other things have succeeded in transforming many citizens from
mere Baltimoreans to actual Hopkinsites. Hopkins does not yet
mean as much to Baltimore as Harvard means to Boston or the
University of Pennsylvania means to Philadelphia. The inhabitants
of the Monumental City, however, are beginning to realize that they
have a great University in their midst.
Hopkins must soon capitalize on this realization. The end of
this month marks the opening of the spring sport schedule. In order to carry out this schedule and to pay the guarantees it will necessitate, the athletic authorities must dispose of a large number of
season tickets. The plan of campaign will be practically the same
as last year. The students will be formed into teams, competition
will be held, and valuable prizes will be awarded to the group and
the individual with the largest number of sales. This spring, however, the salesmen will have a more interested and more sympathetic
citizenry to deal with.
Our track team is famous throughout the country; lacrosse has
grown in popularity by leaps and bounds; the nine promises to be the
best in years; the citizens of Baltimore are interested. Success depends solely upon the efforts of the undergraduates and there is no
excuse for failure.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 4, 1924

A COLLEGE TOWN
Hopkins and Hopkins' activities have more friends now than ever
before. The Maryland football game, notable track successes and
other things have succeeded in transforming many citizens from
mere Baltimoreans to actual Hopkinsites. Hopkins does not yet
mean as much to Baltimore as Harvard means to Boston or the
University of Pennsylvania means to Philadelphia. The inhabitants
of the Monumental City, however, are beginning to realize that they
have a great University in their midst.
Hopkins must soon capitalize on this realization. The end of
this month marks the opening of the spring sport schedule. In order to carry out this schedule and to pay the guarantees it will necessitate, the athletic authorities must dispose of a large number of
season tickets. The plan of campaign will be practically the same
as last year. The students will be formed into teams, competition
will be held, and valuable prizes will be awarded to the group and
the individual with the largest number of sales. This spring, however, the salesmen will have a more interested and more sympathetic
citizenry to deal with.
Our track team is famous throughout the country; lacrosse has
grown in popularity by leaps and bounds; the nine promises to be the
best in years; the citizens of Baltimore are interested. Success depends solely upon the efforts of the undergraduates and there is no
excuse for failure.

Hopkins and Hopkins' activities have more friends now than ever
before. The Maryland football game, notable track successes and
other things have succeeded in transforming many citizens from

mean as much to Baltimore as Harvard means to Boston or the
University of Pennsylvania means to Philadelphia. The inhabitants
of the Monumental City, however, are beginning to realize that they
have a great University in their midst.
Hopkins must soon capitalize on this realization. The end of
this month marks the opening of the spring sport schedule. In order to carry out this schedule and to pay the guarantees it will necessitate, the athletic authorities must dispose of a large number of
season tickets. The plan of campaign will be practically the same
as last year. The students will be formed into teams, competition
will be held, and valuable prizes will be awarded to the group and
the individual with the largest number of sales. This spring, however, the salesmen will have a more interested and more sympathetic
citizenry to deal with.
Our track team is famous throughout the country; lacrosse has
grown in popularity by leaps and bounds; the nine promises to be the
best in years; the citizens of Baltimore are interested. Success depends solely upon the efforts of the undergraduates and there is no
excuse for failure.

Hopkins and Hopkins' activities have more friends now than ever

mean as much to Baltimore as Harvard means to Boston or the
University of Pennsylvania means to Philadelphia. The inhabitants
of the Monumental City, however, are beginning to realize that they
have a great University in their midst.
Hopkins must soon capitalize on this realization. The end of
this month marks the opening of the spring sport schedule. In order to carry out this schedule and to pay the guarantees it will necessitate, the athletic authorities must dispose of a large number of
season tickets. The plan of campaign will be practically the same
as last year. The students will be formed into teams, competition
will be held, and valuable prizes will be awarded to the group and
the individual with the largest number of sales. This spring, however, the salesmen will have a more interested and more sympathetic
citizenry to deal with.
Our track team is famous throughout the country; lacrosse has
grown in popularity by leaps and bounds; the nine promises to be the
best in years; the citizens of Baltimore are interested. Success depends solely upon the efforts of the undergraduates and there is no
excuse for failure.
